alert.note: Alert for Buncombe (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 2:22PM EST until January 10 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Carolina... Swannanoa River At Biltmore affecting Buncombe County. .Heavy rain has ended across the Swannanoa River valley. Storm-total rainfall of 3-4 inches occurred across the valley. Significant flows are still occurring along the Swannanoa River near Black Mountain and it will take several hours for the floodwave to work downstream to Biltmore Village and the French Broad River. Minor flooding along the Swannanoa River, including around Biltmore Village, is expected through. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Swannanoa River at Biltmore. * WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Minor Flood Stage. Backwater effects from the Swannanoa River may be causing flooding along Sweeten Creek forcing floodwaters onto Garfield St. Swannanoa River floodwaters are approaching and may be flooding parts of Swannanoa River Rd. (NC 81), Caledonia Rd., Glendale Ave., and Thompson St. At 11.5 feet, Minor Flooding continues. Swannanoa River and Sweeten Creek floodwaters are approaching buildings on Garfield St. and Decatur St. and initial flooding of these structures may be imminent. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:00 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 8.8 feet and rising rapidly. - Action/Advisory Stage is 8.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above Minor Flood Stage by 4pm and reach a crest of 11.0 feet by 7pm this evening It will then fall below Minor Flood Stage late tonight. - Minor Flood Stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued beforeWednesday afternoon at 100 PM EST.
